summary: Rounding makes numbers friendlier to use. We keep the number close, but easier to read and compute with.

concepts.title: Place Value Refresher
concepts.kid_friendly: Digits to the left of the decimal are ones, tens, hundreds… To the right are tenths, hundredths, thousandths…

concepts.title: Rounding Rule (Five or More, Raise the Score!)
concepts.kid_friendly: 1) Find the place you're rounding to. 2) Look ONE digit to the right. 3) If it's 5,6,7,8,9 → add 1 to your place. If it's 0,1,2,3,4 → keep it the same. 4) Drop all digits to the right.

latex.rule: \text{If next digit} \ge 5 \Rightarrow \text{round up; else round down.}

notes: If the place you round goes from 9 to 10, carry to the left (e.g., 2.995 to hundredths → 3.00).
Trailing zeros may be written to show the place you rounded to (e.g., 3.4 rounded to hundredths is 3.40).

worked_examples.title: Round 12.4567 to the hundredths
steps: Hundredths is the second digit after the decimal (the 5).
Look to the right (thousandths = 6). 6 ≥ 5 → round up.
Increase 5 to 6 and drop the rest.

worked_examples.title: Round 3.241 to the tenths
steps: Next digit is 4 (< 5) → keep the tenths.

worked_examples.title: Carrying Example: round 2.995 to hundredths
steps: 9 rounds up to 10 → write 0 and carry 1 to tenths: 2.995 → 3.00.

teaching_tips: Have students underline the target place and circle the next digit.
Use the chant: "Five or more, raise the score; four or less, let it rest."
Keep place-value meaning by writing trailing zeros when appropriate (3.20 shows tenths rounded to hundredths).

exercises.instructions: Round each number to the requested place. Show one sentence of reasoning (which next digit you used).

easy.explain: Next digit is 3 (<5), so the tenths stays 7.
Next digit is 6 (≥5), so 24 hundredths → 25 hundredths.

medium.explain: Next digit is 9 (≥5), so 34 hundredths → 35 hundredths.
Tenths is 9; next digit 9 (≥5) so 9 tenths rounds to 10 tenths → carry to 1.0.
Next digit is 9 (≥5), so 404 thousandths → 405 thousandths.
Next digit is 5 (≥5), so 14 hundredths → 15 hundredths.

challenge.prompt: Round 29.995 to the hundredths AND to the tenths.
A number rounds to 4.6 to the tenths and to 4.60 to the hundredths. Give one possible original number.
challenge.explain: To tenths: values from 4.55 to 4.649 round to 4.6; to hundredths: must land at 4.60 → original could be 4.595–4.6049…

challenge.prompt: Round 0.0499 to the hundredths and explain why adding a zero changes nothing.
challenge.explain: Next digit is 9 → round up to 0.05. 0.050 = 0.05 (trailing zero).
Tenths 9 (≥5) → ones go from 199 to 200 (carry across the 9s).

extreme.prompt: A measurement is 15.249… (the 9s continue forever). Round to the hundredths.
extreme.explain: Infinite 9s mean the next digit is effectively ≥5; round up.

extreme.prompt: Round −2.65 to the tenths (be careful with negatives!).
extreme.explain: Next digit is 5 → round the tenths away from 0 (more negative).

extreme.prompt: Find a number that rounds to 0.3 to the tenths but rounds to 0.29 to the hundredths.
extreme.explain: To tenths: 0.295 → 0.3; to hundredths: 0.295 → 0.30? Wait—hundredths uses next digit 5 → rounds up. So choose 0.2945…0.2949 to get 0.29. One valid: 0.2946.

extreme.prompt: A box of length 3.456 m is printed as 3.46 m after rounding. What place was it rounded to, and what interval of true lengths would round to 3.46 m?
extreme.explain: Hundredths: numbers from 3.4550… up to (but not including) 3.465 round to 3.46.
